African Parrots

Meyer's Parrot

A small, compact parrot with a brownish-grey head and back, a turquoise or blue belly, and bright yellow markings on the crown and the bend of the wing.

Origin
Africa
Size
8-9 inches (20-23 cm). Weight: 100-135g (3.5-4.8 oz)
Weight
117g avg.
Noise Level
Quiet. Considered one of the quietest parrot species, they tend to chatter and whistle softly to themselves.

Looking for a Meyer's Parrot?

See Available Meyer's Parrot Listings

Species Ratings

Talking Ability 3/10
Noise Level 2/10
Social Needs 9/10
Cuddliness 5/10

Temperament & Personality

Known for being exceptionally quiet, gentle, and charming. They are not as demanding or high-energy as many other parrots, making them great companions for calmer households.

Vocalization & Talking Ability

Not known for their talking ability. They may learn a few words, but their vocalizations are mostly a pleasant mix of soft chirps and whistles.

Dietary Needs

A standard diet of good-quality pellets, fresh vegetables, and some fruit is sufficient. They enjoy a variety of foods.

Health & Lifespan

Can live for 25-35 years. Can be prone to aspergillosis if their environment is not kept clean and dry. Otherwise, they are quite hardy.

Housing Requirements

Excellent for apartments due to their quiet nature. A minimum cage size of 24"W x 18"D x 24"H is appropriate.

Common Questions About Meyer's Parrot

What is the lifespan of a Meyer's Parrot?

The Meyer's Parrot typically lives for 25-35 years. With proper care, diet, and regular vet check-ups, they can live a full and healthy life.

Is the Meyer's Parrot good for beginners?

This species is rated as 'intermediate' care level. They require specific attention, socialization, or dietary needs that may challenge first-time owners.

Where does the Meyer's Parrot come from?

The Meyer's Parrot is native to Africa.

More African Parrots

Brown-headed Parrot

Quiet. Considered one of the quietest Poicephalus species, they tend to communicate with soft whistles and chirps.

Cape Parrot

Moderate to Loud. They have a powerful call and can be quite vocal, especially during the morning and evening.

Congo African Grey

Moderate to Loud. Can develop loud screams, especially if seeking attention.
